elements.content: The hard–soft-acid–base (HSAB) and dual-ligand strategies have been used to construct a pillar-layer luminescent metal–organic framework (MOF) {[Zn2(TRZ)2(DBTDC-O2)]·DMAc} n (1), in which H2DBTDC-O2 = S,S-dioxodibenzothiophen-3,7-dicarboxylic acid and HTRZ = 1,2,4-triazole. Thanks to its high stability in water and quadrangle microporous channels, MOF 1 can be served as a platform of recyclable multi-responsive luminescent sensor for Fe3+, Al3+, SiF6 2–, Cr2O7 2–, nitrofurantoin (NFT), and nitrofurazone (NFZ) in water. This is the first MOF-based sensor for detecting SiF6 2– anion via luminescent enhancement effect. Significantly, 1 also represents a unique example to probe NFZ or NFT by using transition metal MOFs in water, which exhibits the most sensitive sensing ability for NFZ (K sv = 5.2 × 104 M–1) and NFT (K sv = 1.8 × 105 M–1) via luminescent quenching.
elements.clean_text: The hard-soft-acid-base (HSAB) and dual-ligand strategies have been used to construct a pillar-layer luminescent metal-organic framework (MOF) {[Zn2(TRZ)2(DBTDC-O2)]⋅DMAc} n  (1), in which H2DBTDC-O2 = S,S-dioxodibenzothiophen-3,7-dicarboxylic acid and HTRZ = 1,2,4-triazole. Thanks to its high stability in water and quadrangle microporous channels, MOF 1 can be served as a platform of recyclable multi-responsive luminescent sensor for Fe3+, Al3+, SiF6 2-, Cr2O7 2-, nitrofurantoin (NFT), and nitrofurazone (NFZ) in water. This is the first MOF-based sensor for detecting SiF6 2- anion via luminescent enhancement effect. Significantly, 1 also represents a unique example to probe NFZ or NFT by using transition metal MOFs in water, which exhibits the most sensitive sensing ability for NFZ (K sv = 5.2 × 104 M-1) and NFT (K sv = 1.8 × 105 M-1) via luminescent quenching.

elements.content: A pillar-layer metal−organic framework material with excellent stability has been rationally constructed based on the dual-ligand and hard−soft-acid−base strategies, which can be served as a rapid, reversible, and multiresponsive luminescent sensor for metal cations, anions, and antibiotic molecules in water.
elements.clean_text: A pillar-layer metal-organic framework material with excellent stability has been rationally constructed based on the dual-ligand and hard-soft-acid-base strategies, which can be served as a rapid, reversible, and multiresponsive luminescent sensor for metal cations, anions, and antibiotic molecules in water.

elements.content: Effective detection of hazardous pollutants from water source is a profoundly important issue on global scale. Pollutions from mines, agriculture, factories, medical industries, or poorly constructed water supply pipes will surely bring forth a devastating effect on the ecological environment and significant biological processes, including physical health. The recent environmental pollutions and crises with river water and under-groundwater have significant amounts of contaminants from assorted agrochemicals, medical institutions, textiles, grazieries, metallurgy, etc., such as aluminum, mercury, dichromate, antibiotics, and so on. The hazardous pollutants could not only contaminate the drinking supply to endanger human health but also infiltrate into soil and accumulate in plants and animals. The propagating rate for exposed people and ecosystems exceeds people’s imagination. There is an urgent need to be able to detect the low levels of hazardous pollutants in water as early as possible, before the concentration of pollutants accumulates in local ecological environment to cause a series of significant damages. Recently, there is a distinctly escalating interest in the design and development of luminescent materials to selectively sense the hazardous pollutants due to their higher efficiency, greater convenience, less waste, and lower cost.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Effective detection of hazardous pollutants from water source is a profoundly important issue on global scale. Pollutions from mines, agriculture, factories, medical industries, or poorly constructed water supply pipes will surely bring forth a devastating effect on the ecological environment and significant biological processes, including physical health. The recent environmental pollutions and crises with river water and under-groundwater have significant amounts of contaminants from assorted agrochemicals, medical institutions, textiles, grazieries, metallurgy, etc., such as aluminum, mercury, dichromate, antibiotics, and so on. The hazardous pollutants could not only contaminate the drinking supply to endanger human health but also infiltrate into soil and accumulate in plants and animals. The propagating rate for exposed people and ecosystems exceeds people's imagination. There is an urgent need to be able to detect the low levels of hazardous pollutants in water as early as possible, before the concentration of pollutants accumulates in local ecological environment to cause a series of significant damages. Recently, there is a distinctly escalating interest in the design and development of luminescent materials to selectively sense the hazardous pollutants due to their higher efficiency, greater convenience, less waste, and lower cost.

elements.content: In this context, luminescent sensors based on metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are especially impressive for their visible color signal by the naked eye, high sensitivity, and easy operation. The detection capability of luminescent MOFs largely originates from the interactions between the porous frameworks and targeted detection analytes, which are accompanied by optical, electrical, or mechanical signal transduction. Fatally, the stability in water remains a critical obstacle to various applications for MOFs under humid environmental and industrial conditions, which is ascribed to the collapse of the pristine frameworks. By now, several strategies for ameliorating the water or moisture susceptibility for MOFs have been explored to boost the metal–ligand bonds and/or guard inorganic clusters from water exposure. Nonetheless, it remains an extremely important challenge to exploit more effective paths to achieve water stable MOFs for practical applications. In the viewpoint of crystal engineering, it is rather difficult to rationally design and prepare the water-stable MOFs with desired frameworks, and the development of appropriate approaches to fabricate such targeting materials is imperative. As we know, the dual-ligand strategy can furnish a unique scaffold to construct specific MOFs with different properties by coordination assemblies. Furthermore, the origin of instability for MOFs crystals is essentially due to the weaker coordination interactions in the structures. On the basis of the hard–soft-acid–base (HSAB) theory, the soft-acid metal cations (such as Zn2+, Cd2+, Cu2+, etc.) are able to form much stronger coordination bonding with the N donor organic ligands (soft-base) than those with the carboxylate ligands (hard-base). However, it is disadvantageous that the stronger is the coordination bonding between metal ions and organic ligands, the poorer is the crystallinity and, also, the smaller is the crystal size of MOFs.
elements.clean_text: In this context, luminescent sensors based on metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are especially impressive for their visible color signal by the naked eye, high sensitivity, and easy operation. The detection capability of luminescent MOFs largely originates from the interactions between the porous frameworks and targeted detection analytes, which are accompanied by optical, electrical, or mechanical signal transduction. Fatally, the stability in water remains a critical obstacle to various applications for MOFs under humid environmental and industrial conditions, which is ascribed to the collapse of the pristine frameworks. By now, several strategies for ameliorating the water or moisture susceptibility for MOFs have been explored to boost the metal-ligand bonds and/or guard inorganic clusters from water exposure. Nonetheless, it remains an extremely important challenge to exploit more effective paths to achieve water stable MOFs for practical applications. In the viewpoint of crystal engineering, it is rather difficult to rationally design and prepare the water-stable MOFs with desired frameworks, and the development of appropriate approaches to fabricate such targeting materials is imperative. As we know, the dual-ligand strategy can furnish a unique scaffold to construct specific MOFs with different properties by coordination assemblies. Furthermore, the origin of instability for MOFs crystals is essentially due to the weaker coordination interactions in the structures. On the basis of the hard-soft-acid-base (HSAB) theory, the soft-acid metal cations (such as Zn2+, Cd2+, Cu2+, etc.) are able to form much stronger coordination bonding with the N donor organic ligands (soft-base) than those with the carboxylate ligands (hard-base). However, it is disadvantageous that the stronger is the coordination bonding between metal ions and organic ligands, the poorer is the crystallinity and, also, the smaller is the crystal size of MOFs.

elements.content: Inspired by these guidelines, we postulate both stability and crystallinity of luminescent MOFs could be finely tuned via the rational choice of metal moieties and organic ligands based on the dual-ligand and HSAB theories. As illustrated in , a dual-ligand pillared-layer MOF normally contains two different functional linkers. The two-dimensional (2D) layer net is constructed with the strong coordination bonds to enhance the stability based on the HSAB theory, and the pillars can support the three-dimensional (3D) framework with porosity and luminescent properties. To confirm such a proof-of-concept, this work reports the design and synthesis of a 3D pillar-layer Zn­(II) MOF material {[Zn2(TRZ)2(DBTDC-O2)]·DMAc} n (1) with the dual organic ligands, S,S-dioxodibenzothiophen-3,7-dicarboxylic acid (H2DBTDC-O2) and 1,2,4-triazole (HTRZ). Due to the closed-shell d10 electron configuration with luminescence for Zn­(II) center, it can be applied as a soft metal site to connect with the soft base HTRZ to generate a stable 2D Zn­(II)–TRZ layered moiety. Also, the rigid carboxylate ligand H2DBTDC-O2 could be used as pillars to extend the layers to construct a desired 3D porous framework. As expected, the luminescent MOF 1 shows excellent stability in water, which can be well used as a platform of recyclable multi-responsive sensor for metal ions, anions, and antibiotics.
elements.clean_text: Inspired by these guidelines, we postulate both stability and crystallinity of luminescent MOFs could be finely tuned via the rational choice of metal moieties and organic ligands based on the dual-ligand and HSAB theories. As illustrated in , a dual-ligand pillared-layer MOF normally contains two different functional linkers. The two-dimensional (2D) layer net is constructed with the strong coordination bonds to enhance the stability based on the HSAB theory, and the pillars can support the three-dimensional (3D) framework with porosity and luminescent properties. To confirm such a proof-of-concept, this work reports the design and synthesis of a 3D pillar-layer Zn(II) MOF material {[Zn2(TRZ)2(DBTDC-O2)]⋅DMAc} n  (1) with the dual organic ligands, S,S-dioxodibenzothiophen-3,7-dicarboxylic acid (H2DBTDC-O2) and 1,2,4-triazole (HTRZ). Due to the closed-shell d10 electron configuration with luminescence for Zn(II) center, it can be applied as a soft metal site to connect with the soft base HTRZ to generate a stable 2D Zn(II)-TRZ layered moiety. Also, the rigid carboxylate ligand H2DBTDC-O2 could be used as pillars to extend the layers to construct a desired 3D porous framework. As expected, the luminescent MOF 1 shows excellent stability in water, which can be well used as a platform of recyclable multi-responsive sensor for metal ions, anions, and antibiotics.

elements.content: All the regents were commercially acquirable and used directly. The organic ligand H2DBTDC-O2 was synthesized as the reported literature. Elemental analysis of C, H and N was performed on a Leeman-Laboratories CE-440 analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curve was performed on a Shimadzu DTG-60A analysis instrument in air conditions from room temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. The Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were carried out in the range of 4000–400 cm–1 on an Avatar-370 (Nicolet) spectrometer (KBr pellets). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) plots were taken on a Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer (40 kV and 40 mA) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at a sweep speed of 0.2° min–1. The UV–vis spectra were performed on a Shimadzu UV-2700 spectrophotometer. The luminescent spectra were recorded on a Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature. All gas adsorption measurements were taken on a surface area analyzer ASAP 2020.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All the regents were commercially acquirable and used directly. The organic ligand H2DBTDC-O2 was synthesized as the reported literature. Elemental analysis of C, H and N was performed on a Leeman-Laboratories CE-440 analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curve was performed on a Shimadzu DTG-60A analysis instrument in air conditions from room temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were carried out in the range of 4000-400 cm-1 on an Avatar-370 (Nicolet) spectrometer (KBr pellets). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) plots were taken on a Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer (40 kV and 40 mA) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at a sweep speed of 0.2° min-1. The UV-vis spectra were performed on a Shimadzu UV-2700 spectrophotometer. The luminescent spectra were recorded on a Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature. All gas adsorption measurements were taken on a surface area analyzer ASAP 2020.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (30 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2DBTDC-O2 (7 mg, 0.023 mmol), HTRZ (7 mg, 0.1 mmol), DMAc (2 mL), MeOH (1 mL), H2O (2 mL), and aqueous solution of HNO3 (2.0 mol L–1, 50 μL) was sealed into a 23 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Colorless block crystals of 1 can be obtained at 90 °C for 3 days in an oven. The final product was collected by filtering and washed by fresh DMAc. Yield: 76% (based on H2DBTDC-O2 ligand). Anal. Calcd for C18H10O6N6SZn2·DMAc (1): C, 40.18; H, 3.20; N, 14.92%. Found: C, 40.12; H, 3.15; N, 14.79%. Synthesis of {[Zn2(TRZ)2(DBTDC-O2)]⋅DMAc} n  (1)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (30 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2DBTDC-O2 (7 mg, 0.023 mmol), HTRZ (7 mg, 0.1 mmol), DMAc (2 mL), MeOH (1 mL), H2O (2 mL), and aqueous solution of HNO3 (2.0 mol L-1, 50 μL) was sealed into a 23 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. Colorless block crystals of 1 can be obtained at 90 °C for 3 days in an oven. The final product was collected by filtering and washed by fresh DMAc. Yield: 76% (based on H2DBTDC-O2 ligand). Anal. Calcd for C18H10O6N6SZn2⋅DMAc (1): C, 40.18; H, 3.20; N, 14.92%. Found: C, 40.12; H, 3.15; N, 14.79%. elements.content: The as-synthesized sample 1 (ca. 50 mg) was dispersed in common solvents (20 mL) for 2 days at room temperature, including H2O, CH3CN, EtOH, toluene, and DMSO. Additionally, the as-synthesized 1 (ca. 50 mg) was soaked in the water solutions (20 mL) with a pH range from 3 (HCl) to 12 (NaOH) for 12 h at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Stability Experiments

The as-synthesized sample 1 (ca. 50 mg) was dispersed in common solvents (20 mL) for 2 days at room temperature, including H2O, CH3CN, EtOH, toluene, and DMSO. Additionally, the as-synthesized 1 (ca. 50 mg) was soaked in the water solutions (20 mL) with a pH range from 3 (HCl) to 12 (NaOH) for 12 h at room temperature.

elements.content: The as-synthesized sample was well ground with a mortar before the measurements. The powder sample of 1 (ca. 3 mg) was added in the water solution (3 mL) of M­(NO3) x (Mx+ = Li+, Na+, Ca2+, Mn2+, Zn2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Pb2+, Al3+ and Fe3+, 1 × 10–4 mol L–1), KX (X = F–, Cl–, Br–, ClO3 –, ClO4 –, Cr2O7 2–, PO4 3–, BrO3 –, IO3 –, and MnO4 –, 1 × 10–4 mol L–1), NaX (X = HPO4 2–, H2PO4 –, HCO3 –, HCOO–, CH3COO–, and SiF6 2–, 1 × 10–4 mol L–1), Zn­(BF4)2 (1 × 10–4 mol L–1), or antibiotics (1 × 10–4 mol L–1) at room temperature. The resultant mixture was stirred by a glass rod to make the sample with good dispersion in the solution. The terminated luminescent data of the corresponding mixture was collected after 2 min.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Sensing Experiments

The as-synthesized sample was well ground with a mortar before the measurements. The powder sample of 1 (ca. 3 mg) was added in the water solution (3 mL) of M(NO3) x  (Mx+ = Li+, Na+, Ca2+, Mn2+, Zn2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Pb2+, Al3+ and Fe3+, 1 × 10-4 mol L-1), KX (X = F-, Cl-, Br-, ClO3 -, ClO4 -, Cr2O7 2-, PO4 3-, BrO3 -, IO3 -, and MnO4 -, 1 × 10-4 mol L-1), NaX (X = HPO4 2-, H2PO4 -, HCO3 -, HCOO-, CH3COO-, and SiF6 2-, 1 × 10-4 mol L-1), Zn(BF4)2 (1 × 10-4 mol L-1), or antibiotics (1 × 10-4 mol L-1) at room temperature. The resultant mixture was stirred by a glass rod to make the sample with good dispersion in the solution. The terminated luminescent data of the corresponding mixture was collected after 2 min.

elements.content: The as-synthesized sample was well ground with a mortar before the measurements. The powder sample of 1 (ca. 3 mg) was added in water (3 mL), which was stirred by a glass rod to make a mixture with good dispersion, and subsequently, that mixture was transferred into a quartz cell of 1 cm width. The quenching tests were carried out by gradually adding analyte of Al3+ (1 × 10–2 mol L–1), Fe3+ (1 × 10–3 mol L–1), SiF6 2– (1 × 10–2 mol L–1), Cr2O7 2– (1 × 10–3 mol L–1), NFZ, or NFT (1 × 10–3 mol L–1) aqueous solution. Each measurement was repeated three times.
elements.clean_text:
Typical Procedure for Luminescence Titration

The as-synthesized sample was well ground with a mortar before the measurements. The powder sample of 1 (ca. 3 mg) was added in water (3 mL), which was stirred by a glass rod to make a mixture with good dispersion, and subsequently, that mixture was transferred into a quartz cell of 1 cm width. The quenching tests were carried out by gradually adding analyte of Al3+ (1 × 10-2 mol L-1), Fe3+ (1 × 10-3 mol L-1), SiF6 2- (1 × 10-2 mol L-1), Cr2O7 2- (1 × 10-3 mol L-1), NFZ, or NFT (1 × 10-3 mol L-1) aqueous solution. Each measurement was repeated three times.

elements.content: The reproducibility of 1 toward sensing Al3+, Fe3+, SiF6 2–, Cr2O7 2–, NFZ, or NFT was studied in aqueous solution. After the first quenching experiment, the powder sample of 1 was recovered by centrifugation and washed by water. The recovered solid was collected and subsequently used in the successive quenching experiments.
elements.clean_text:
Recyclable Luminescence Sensing Experiments

The reproducibility of 1 toward sensing Al3+, Fe3+, SiF6 2-, Cr2O7 2-, NFZ, or NFT was studied in aqueous solution. After the first quenching experiment, the powder sample of 1 was recovered by centrifugation and washed by water. The recovered solid was collected and subsequently used in the successive quenching experiments.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction data for 1 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD-based diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184 A) using the φ–ω scan technique at room temperature. Multiscan absorption corrections were applied with the SADABS program. The crystal structure was determined by direct methods with SHELXT 6 and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique using SHELXL-2015 through OLEX2 interface program. All non-H atoms were located successfully and refined by anisotropic thermal parameters. Attempt to locate and model the highly disordered DMA guest in the structure was unsuccessful. Therefore, the SQUEEZE routine, a part of the PLATON software package, was used to calculate the disorder areas and remove the diffraction contribution to afford a set of solvent free diffraction intensity. The DMA solvent is not included in the crystal data, and the chemical formula for as-synthesized 1 was determined based on the crystal data combined with the results of elemental analysis and TGA. Crystal data of 1 are summarized in and the selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table S1.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structure Determination and Refinement

X-ray diffraction data for 1 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD-based diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184 A) using the φ-ω scan technique at room temperature. Multiscan absorption corrections were applied with the SADABS program. The crystal structure was determined by direct methods with SHELXT 6 and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique using SHELXL-2015  through OLEX2 interface program. All non-H atoms were located successfully and refined by anisotropic thermal parameters. Attempt to locate and model the highly disordered DMA guest in the structure was unsuccessful. Therefore, the SQUEEZE routine, a part of the PLATON software package, was used to calculate the disorder areas and remove the diffraction contribution to afford a set of solvent free diffraction intensity. The DMA solvent is not included in the crystal data, and the chemical formula for as-synthesized 1 was determined based on the crystal data combined with the results of elemental analysis and TGA. Crystal data of 1 are summarized in  and the selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table S1.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction study shows that 1 crystallizes in tetragonal space group P 421/c. The asymmetrical unit of 1 involves two independent Zn­(II) ions, one DBTDC-O2 2– ligand, and two TRZ– ligands (Figure S2). As depicted in , each TRZ– ligand connects three Zn­(II) cations through μ1,2,4-bridging mode to form a 2D Zn–TRZ layer (Zn–N = 2.0251–2.0406 Å) with 4.82 topology. Notably, the 2D Zn–TRZ layer is obviously corrugated due to the existence of tetrahedrally coordinated Zn­(II) nodes. Moreover, each linear ditopic carboxylate DBTDC-O2 2– is linked to two independent Zn­(II) metals (Zn–O = 1.9199–2.3564 Å). As a result, the adjacent 2D layers are extended to construct a 3D pillar-layered structure with microporous quadrangle channels (). After the elimination of all guest molecule, the solvent accessible volume in 1 is 44.9% of the unit cell volume, as calculated by PLATON/VOID routine.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Analysis

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction study shows that 1 crystallizes in tetragonal space group P 421/c. The asymmetrical unit of 1 involves two independent Zn(II) ions, one DBTDC-O2 2- ligand, and two TRZ- ligands (Figure S2). As depicted in , each TRZ- ligand connects three Zn(II) cations through μ1,2,4-bridging mode to form a 2D Zn-TRZ layer (Zn-N = 2.0251-2.0406 Å) with 4.82 topology. Notably, the 2D Zn-TRZ layer is obviously corrugated due to the existence of tetrahedrally coordinated Zn(II) nodes. Moreover, each linear ditopic carboxylate DBTDC-O2 2- is linked to two independent Zn(II) metals (Zn-O = 1.9199-2.3564 Å). As a result, the adjacent 2D layers are extended to construct a 3D pillar-layered structure with microporous quadrangle channels (). After the elimination of all guest molecule, the solvent accessible volume in 1 is 44.9% of the unit cell volume, as calculated by PLATON/VOID routine.

elements.content: As shown in Figure S3, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) plot of MOF 1 shows a weight loss of 13.4% before 330 °C, corresponding to the removal of guest solvent molecule (calculated 13.3%). The phase purity of the as-synthesized sample could be confirmed by the PXRD pattern, where the characteristic peaks match well with those of the simulated PXRD pattern based on the single crystal data (Figure S4). Furthermore, 1 shows good stability in common organic solvents and water for 2 days, and in the aqueous solutions with a pH range from 3 (HCl) to 12 (NaOH) for 12 h at room temperature (). The results further illustrate that the HSAB and dual-ligand strategies can synergistically boost the stability of MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal and Chemical Stability

As shown in Figure S3, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) plot of MOF 1 shows a weight loss of 13.4% before 330 °C, corresponding to the removal of guest solvent molecule (calculated 13.3%). The phase purity of the as-synthesized sample could be confirmed by the PXRD pattern, where the characteristic peaks match well with those of the simulated PXRD pattern based on the single crystal data (Figure S4). Furthermore, 1 shows good stability in common organic solvents and water for 2 days, and in the aqueous solutions with a pH range from 3 (HCl) to 12 (NaOH) for 12 h at room temperature (). The results further illustrate that the HSAB and dual-ligand strategies can synergistically boost the stability of MOFs.

elements.content: To reveal the permanent porosity of 1, the as-synthesized crystals were immersed into dry methanol and desolvated by supercritical CO2 drying method at 0–10 °C. The PXRD pattern of the activated sample demonstrates that the original framework can retain a high crystallinity (Figure S5). As shown in a, MOF 1 reveals a fully reversible type-I N2 sorption isotherm at 77 K. The initial adsorption of N2 increases sharply to 150 cm3 g–1 at low pressures (P/P 0 = 0.05) and reaches the maximal adsorption capacity of 124 cm3 g–1 at P/P 0 = 1, which manifests the presence of intrinsic micropores in 1. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area is calculated to be 532 m2 g–1. In addition, the maximal CO2 adsorption capacities are 52 cm3 g–1 (2.3 mmol g–1, 273 K) and 36 cm3 g–1 (1.6 mmol g–1, 298 K) under 1 atm pressure (b). The maximal CO2 adsorption enthalpy (Q st) is 27.6 kJ mol–1 at zero loading (Figure S6), as calculated from the adsorption data at 273 and 298 K using the virial method.

elements.content: Previous researches have shown that H2DBTDC-O2 can be a luminescent source of MOFs due to its highly conjugated π-electron rich system, whereas HTRZ only shows very weak luminescence. The luminescent emission spectra for HTRZ and H2DBTDC-O2 in the solid state were investigated at room temperature, which show the emission bands at 421 nm (λem = 350 nm) and 394 nm (λem = 345 nm), respectively (Figures S7 and S8). In comparison, 1 displays an emission band at 392 nm under an excitation of 327 nm (Figure S9). The results indicate that the luminescence of 1 is mostly attributed to the organic linker H2DBTDC-O2. In addition, the luminescence intensity for 1 can keep well in water for 2 days (Figure S10).

Luminescent Properties

elements.content: The obvious luminescence of MOF 1 promotes us to explore its sensing ability to the common metal cations. The finely ground samples of 1 were dispersed in the water solutions of different metal ions and their corresponding luminescence curves were monitored, which indicate that the metal cations afford significantly different luminescence effects toward MOF 1 (a). The luminescent intensity of 1 in Al3+ water solution drastically increases, while the other metal cations lead to the decrease of luminescent intensity at different levels. Interestingly, 1 dispersed in Fe3+ water solution shows a drastic luminescent quenching behavior. The different luminescent effects of Al3+ and Fe3+ demonstrate that 1 can be considered as a potential luminescent probe for Al3+ and Fe3+ in water. The luminescent response rates of 1 to Al3+ and Fe3+ in aqueous solutions were measured at different time intervals (b). Upon the addition of Al3+ and Fe3+, the corresponding luminescent intensity of 1 will immediately change and reach a stable value after 50 s that can be further remained for a long time. Furthermore, the anti-interference experiments were implemented to further check the high selectivity of 1 for detection of Fe3+ or Al3+ cation in water (Figure S11). That is, the interference of other coexisting metal ions in solution was tested for control experiment to prove the selectivity of 1. As a result, once Fe3+ was dripped in a water solution of equivalent 1 and other mixed cations, the luminescence intensity will also remarkably weaken. In contrast, the luminescence enhancement can be observed immediately when Al3+ was introduced. These results demonstrate that the interference from other common metal cations can be ignored, which confirm the high selectivity of 1 for Fe3+ and Al3+ detection.

elements.content: To explore the detection effects of 1 as a Fe3+ or Al3+ probe, concentration-dependent experiments were further taken. As depicted in c, the luminescent intensity of 1 gradually decreases with the increasing concentration of the Fe3+ ion. The quenching efficiency could be quantitatively evaluated by the quenching constant (K sv) that is calculated from the Stern–Volmer equation: (I 0/I) = K sv[M] + 1. Herein, I 0 and I are the luminescent intensities of 1 without and with the addition of Fe3+, respectively; [M] expresses the molar concentration of quencher Fe3+. Meanwhile, the detection limit of Fe3+ can be calculated from 3δ/slope (δ: standard error), which is as low as 4.61 × 10–6 mol L–1 (Figure S12). The detail analysis further demonstrates that there is a good linear relationship (R 2 = 0.9971) between the value of I 0/I – 1 and the amount of Fe3+ in the low concentration range of 0 to 2.5 × 10–4 mol L–1 (c inset). The corresponding K sv value is 1.0 × 104 M–1 for Fe3+, which is comparable to those of the reported MOF-based sensors (Table S2). According to the UV–vis absorption spectra of all metal ions, only Fe3+ in aqueous solution exhibits the spectral overlap with the excitation spectrum of 1, and the other metal cations have no evident absorption bands in this range (Figure S13). Therefore, the luminescent quenching is mainly attributed to the competitive absorption of the excitation wavelength energy between 1 and Fe3+ cation. Notably, the corresponding emission intensity of 1 will enhance approximately 2.8 times with the increasing amount of Al3+ to 2.6 × 10–4 mol L–1, which has rarely been observed for MOFs. A careful examination of the luminescence indicates that the emission spectrum shows an obvious red-shift of ca. 34 nm as compared with that of 1 without Al3+ (d). Moreover, there is a good linear relationship (R 2 = 0.9965) between the luminescent intensity and the amount of Al3+ (d inset). Meanwhile, the detection limit of Al3+ could reach 4.43 × 10–6 mol L–1 (Figure S14). The definite mechanisms of MOFs as luminescent sensors have been explored, while there is still no eventually proper interpretation so far, especially for the luminescent enhancement toward metal ions. In our case, the PXRD patterns (Figure S15) demonstrate that the MOF structure can be retained well after the sensing experiment. The greatest possibility is that the interactions between the organic ligands and Al3+ ions may facilitate the transition of electrons to increase the intensity of luminescence emission, which is similar to the previous reports. Further, the reusable performance plays a vitally important role in luminescence detection. 1 can be easily reused by centrifuged and washed with water, which can almost retain the original luminescent intensity and detection effect (, parts e and f). The PXRD patterns of 1 after five cycles (Figure S15) indicate that the skeleton can be well retained.

elements.content: Multifarious anions were chosen to evaluate the anion-sensing capacities of 1 by a similar procedure to that for metal cations. As illustrated in a, the Cr2O7 2– anion results in remarkably luminescent quenching effect, whereas the SiF6 2– anion enhances the luminescence intensity of 1. There is almost no change for the luminescence intensity of 1 in the water solutions of other common anions. Further, the anti-interference sensing capacity to Cr2O7 2– or SiF6 2– was estimated via the competing experiments. The equivalent 1 was dispersed in the water solutions of mixed anions without or with Cr2O7 2–/SiF6 2–, which indicates that the quenching or enhancement effect of Cr2O7 2– or SiF6 2– is almost not influenced by the coexisting anions (Figure S16). The luminescent response rates of 1 toward Cr2O7 2– or SiF6 2– were tested at different time intervals, which show that the emission intensity can be rapidly stabilized (b).

elements.content: The detection effect for Cr2O7 2– or SiF6 2– was also checked by similar concentration-dependent experiments. As expected, the reduction of emissive intensity is related to the concentration of Cr2O7 2– (c). The K sv value of Cr2O7 2– is calculated to be 1.24 × 104 M–1 with a good linear relationship (R 2 = 0.9979) at a low concentration range (c inset), which is significantly more sensitive than those of the reported MOFs (Table S3). In addition, the detection limit of Cr2O7 2– is 2.55 × 10–6 mol L–1 (Figure S17). More interestingly, it is the first report that the emission peak position shows a significant red-shift of ca. 23 nm as compared with that of 1. The luminescent quenching may be attributed to the competitive absorption of excitation wavelength energy between 1 and Cr2O7 2– anion according to the UV–vis spectra, which is similar to that of Fe3+ detection (Figure S18). However, with the increase of SiF6 2– concentration from 0 to 8.0 × 10–4 mol L–1, the corresponding emission intensity enhances approximately 4.3 times, which has not been observed for MOFs toward SiF6 2– detection in water (d). There is a good linear relationship (R 2 = 0.9958) between the value of I and the amount of SiF6 2– below the concentration of 4.5 × 10–4 mol L–1 (d inset). The corresponding detection limit is calculated to be 1.35 × 10–5 mol L–1 (Figure S19). Meanwhile, the emission peak position exhibits a blue-shift of 15 nm, which may be attributed to the interactions between the organic ligands and SiF6 2–. The reused samples could be easily obtained by washing several times with water. The cycling experiments for sensing Cr2O7 2– or SiF6 2– anion in water demonstrate that the detection efficiency can be retained at least five times (, parts e and f) and the corresponding PXRD patterns further confirm the stability of 1 (Figure S15).

elements.content: Only few MOFs have been successfully applied to detect antibiotics, in spite of its significant requirement in practice. In this work, eight frequently used antibiotics were selected to test the detection effect of 1 in water, including nitrofurazone (NFZ), nitrofurantoin (NFT), metronidazole (MDZ), dimetridazole (DTZ), sulfamethazine (SMZ), chloramphenicol (CAP), thiamphenicol (THI), and penicillin (PCL). The luminescent emissions of 1 were recorded in the presence of diverse antibiotics in water, which exhibit a significant luminescent quenching for NFZ or NFT (a). The order of quenching efficiency is NFT > NFZ > DTZ> MDZ > SMZ > PCL > CAP > THI. This result shows that MOF 1 is a potential luminescence sensor to recognize NFZ or NFT in water via luminescent quenching. Moreover, the luminescence intensity of 1 decreases a little after adding other antibiotics, which however will be completely quenched when equimolar NFZ or NFT is further added (Figure S20). Such anti-interference experiments indicate that 1 has the high selectivity for NFZ or NFT in water even in the presence of several other antibiotics. In addition, the luminescent response rates of 1 toward NFZ and NFT in water were tested at different time intervals (b). After the addition of NFZ or NFT (1.0 × 10–5 mol L–1), the luminescent intensity of 1 will decrease immediately and reach to the minimum value after 50 s, which further can be retained for a long time.

elements.content: To further explore the sensing capacity of 1 to NFZ or NFT, the titration trials were performed by adding NFZ or NFT to the sample of 1 drop by drop. As shown in parts c and d of , the corresponding luminescence intensity of 1 distinctly reduces with the incremental amounts of NFZ or NFT. A closer examination reveals that the emission of 1 produces an obvious red-shift of 43 and 67 nm with the introduction of NFZ and NFT, respectively. Such a shift phenomenon due to NFZ or NFT has been first found for luminescent Zn­(II)-MOFs in water. Moreover, the quenching effect can also be quantitatively calculated by the Stern–Volmer equation of the plots of (I 0/I – 1) vs the concentrations of NFZ or NFT in the low concentrations. As shown in parts c and d of , the corresponding K sv values for NFZ and NFT are 5.2 × 104 M–1 (R 2 = 0.9968) and 1.8 × 105 M–1 (R 2 = 0.9945), respectively, indicating that 1 is the most efficient luminescent MOFs-based sensor for such antibiotics (Table S4). The corresponding detection limits of NFZ and NFT are 4.04 × 10–7 and 3.53 × 10–7 mol L–1, respectively (Figures S21 and S22). As for the recyclability, the luminescent MOF 1 can be continuously recollected from the solution by simply centrifuged and washed with distilled water. The reused crystals well retain the luminescent intensity as that of the as-synthesized sample and can be recycled at least five cycles (e,f and S15). These results suggest that 1 shows excellent stability and recyclability in water as a sensing material for NFZ or NFT.

elements.content: It is meaningful to study the luminescence quenching mechanism and highly selective ability of 1. From the PXRD patterns (Figure S15), it can be excluded that the luminescence quenching is caused by framework collapse of 1. Also, the quick and easy regeneration of 1 illustrates that the luminescence quenching is not a result of the guest molecule adsorption. In fact, the luminescence quenching is always caused by electron transfer from the conduction bands (CB) of MOFs to the LUMO orbitals of antibiotics, due to the relatively higher energy levels for the former. The different band gaps between the CB of MOF 1 and the LUMOs of antibiotic may lead to remarkably diverse driving forces for electron transfer. As shown in Table S5, the LUMO energy levels of antibiotics are almost well consistent with their luminescence quenching efficiencies, that is, NFZ, NFT > MDZ, DTZ, SMZ > THI, PCL. Notably, the LUMO energy level of CAP is closest to NFZ or NFT in this series of antibiotics, which however shows almost none quenching effect. This reveals that electron-transfer is not the sole contributing factor for luminescence quenching. In the UV–vis spectra, the strong spectral overlap between the absorption spectra of NFT or NFZ and the emission/excitation spectra of 1 in water is observed (Figure S23), illustrating that the quenching effect of NFT or NFZ is significantly larger than the other antibiotics. As a consequence, both factors will work together to lead to the significant luminescence quenching effect for NFZ and NFT.

Notably, the LUMO energy level of CAP is closest to NFZ or NFT in this series of antibiotics, which however shows almost none quenching effect. In the UV-vis spectra, the strong spectral overlap between the absorption spectra of NFT or NFZ and the emission/excitation spectra of 1 in water is observed (Figure S23), illustrating that the quenching effect of NFT or NFZ is significantly larger than the other antibiotics. As a consequence, both factors will work together to lead to the significant luminescence quenching effect for NFZ and NFT.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully designed and synthesized a microporous pillar-layer MOF with excellent stability based on the synergetic dual-ligand and HSAB strategies, which could be served as a rapid, reversible, and multi-responsive luminescent sensor in water. More importantly, 1 is the first MOF-based sensor for detecting SiF6 2– anion via luminescent enhancement effect and exhibits the most sensitive sensing ability for NFZ (K sv = 5.2 × 104 M–1) and NFT (K sv = 1.8 × 105 M–1) via luminescent quenching effect in water. We anticipate that this work can provide a general avenue to designing multifunctional luminescence MOFs with extraordinary stability.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully designed and synthesized a microporous pillar-layer MOF with excellent stability based on the synergetic dual-ligand and HSAB strategies, which could be served as a rapid, reversible, and multi-responsive luminescent sensor in water. More importantly, 1 is the first MOF-based sensor for detecting SiF6 2- anion via luminescent enhancement effect and exhibits the most sensitive sensing ability for NFZ (K sv = 5.2 × 104 M-1) and NFT (K sv = 1.8 × 105 M-1) via luminescent quenching effect in water. We anticipate that this work can provide a general avenue to designing multifunctional luminescence MOFs with extraordinary stability.

cln_elements.content:
As shown in Figure S3, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) plot of MOF 1 shows a weight loss of 13.4% before 330 °C, corresponding to the removal of guest solvent molecule (calculated 13.3%). The phase purity of the as-synthesized sample could be confirmed by the PXRD pattern, where the characteristic peaks match well with those of the simulated PXRD pattern based on the single crystal data (Figure S4). Furthermore, 1 shows good stability in common organic solvents and water for 2 days, and in the aqueous solutions with a pH range from 3 (HCl) to 12 (NaOH) for 12 h at room temperature (). The results further illustrate that the HSAB and dual-ligand strategies can synergistically boost the stability of MOFs.

Gas Sorption

To reveal the permanent porosity of 1, the as-synthesized crystals were immersed into dry methanol and desolvated by supercritical CO2 drying method at 0–10 °C. The PXRD pattern of the activated sample demonstrates that the original framework can retain a high crystallinity (Figure S5). As shown in a, MOF 1 reveals a fully reversible type-I N2 sorption isotherm at 77 K. The initial adsorption of N2 increases sharply to 150 cm3 g–1 at low pressures (P/P 0 = 0.05) and reaches the maximal adsorption capacity of 124 cm3 g–1 at P/P 0 = 1, which manifests the presence of intrinsic micropores in 1. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area is calculated to be 532 m2 g–1. In addition, the maximal CO2 adsorption capacities are 52 cm3 g–1 (2.3 mmol g–1, 273 K) and 36 cm3 g–1 (1.6 mmol g–1, 298 K) under 1 atm pressure (b). The maximal CO2 adsorption enthalpy (Q st) is 27.6 kJ mol–1 at zero loading (Figure S6), as calculated from the adsorption data at 273 and 298 K using the virial method.

Luminescent Properties

Previous researches have shown that H2DBTDC-O2 can be a luminescent source of MOFs due to its highly conjugated π-electron rich system, whereas HTRZ only shows very weak luminescence. The luminescent emission spectra for HTRZ and H2DBTDC-O2 in the solid state were investigated at room temperature, which show the emission bands at 421 nm (λem = 350 nm) and 394 nm (λem = 345 nm), respectively (Figures S7 and S8). In comparison, 1 displays an emission band at 392 nm under an excitation of 327 nm (Figure S9). The results indicate that the luminescence of 1 is mostly attributed to the organic linker H2DBTDC-O2. In addition, the luminescence intensity for 1 can keep well in water for 2 days (Figure S10).
